PERSONAE.TITLE: Dramatis Personae
PERSONAE.PERSONA: DUKE OF GLOUCESTER, uncle to the King, and Protector.
DUKE OF BEDFORD, uncle to the King, and Regent of France.
THOMAS BEAUFORT, Duke of Exeter, great-uncle to the King.
HENRY BEAUFORT, great-uncle to the King, Bishop of Winchester, and afterwards Cardinal.
JOHN BEAUFORT, Earl, afterwards Duke, of Somerset.
RICHARD PLANTAGENET, son of Richard late Earl of Cambridge, afterwards Duke of York.
LORD TALBOT, afterwards Earl of Shrewsbury.
VERNON, of the White-Rose or York faction.
BASSET, of the Red-Rose or Lancaster faction.
CHARLES, Dauphin, and afterwards King, of France.
REIGNIER, Duke of Anjou, and titular King of Naples.
Master-Gunner of Orleans, and his Son.
General of the French forces in Bourdeaux.
An old Shepherd, father to Joan la Pucelle.
MARGARET, daughter to Reignier, afterwards married to King Henry.
JOAN LA PUCELLE, commonly called Joan of Arc.
Lords, Warders of the Tower, Heralds, Officers, Soldiers, Messengers, and Attendants.

PLAY.SCNDESCR: SCENE Partly in England, and partly in France.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Westminster Abbey.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Dead March. Enter the Funeral of KING HENRY the Fifth, attended on by Dukes of BEDFORD, Regent of France; GLOUCESTER, Protector; and EXETER, Earl of WARWICK, the BISHOP OF WINCHESTER, Heralds, &c

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Hung be the heavens with black, yield day to night!
Comets, importing change of times and states,
Brandish your crystal tresses in the sky,
And with them scourge the bad revolting stars
That have consented unto Henry's death!
King Henry the Fifth, too famous to live long!
England ne'er lost a king of so much worth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: England ne'er had a king until his time.
Virtue he had, deserving to command:
His brandish'd sword did blind men with his beams:
His arms spread wider than a dragon's wings;
His sparking eyes, replete with wrathful fire,
More dazzled and drove back his enemies
Than mid-day sun fierce bent against their faces.
What should I say? his deeds exceed all speech:
He ne'er lift up his hand but conquered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EXETER
SPEECH.LINE: We mourn in black: why mourn we not in blood?
Henry is dead and never shall revive:
Upon a wooden coffin we attend,
And death's dishonourable victory
We with our stately presence glorify,
Like captives bound to a triumphant car.
What! shall we curse the planets of mishap
That plotted thus our glory's overthrow?
Or shall we think the subtle-witted French
Conjurers and sorcerers, that afraid of him
By magic verses have contrived his end?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: He was a king bless'd of the King of kings.
Unto the French the dreadful judgement-day
So dreadful will not be as was his sight.
The battles of the Lord of hosts he fought:
The church's prayers made him so prosperous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: The church! where is it? Had not churchmen pray'd,
His thread of life had not so soon decay'd:
None do you like but an effeminate prince,
Whom, like a school-boy, you may over-awe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Gloucester, whate'er we like, thou art protector
And lookest to command the prince and realm.
Thy wife is proud; she holdeth thee in awe,
More than God or religious churchmen may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Name not religion, for thou lovest the flesh,
And ne'er throughout the year to church thou go'st
Except it be to pray against thy foes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Cease, cease these jars and rest your minds in peace:
Let's to the altar: heralds, wait on us:
Instead of gold, we'll offer up our arms:
Since arms avail not now that Henry's dead.
Posterity, await for wretched years,
When at their mothers' moist eyes babes shall suck,
Our isle be made a nourish of salt tears,
And none but women left to wail the dead.
Henry the Fifth, thy ghost I invocate:
Prosper this realm, keep it from civil broils,
Combat with adverse planets in the heavens!
A far more glorious star thy soul will make
Than Julius Caesar or bright--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: My honourable lords, health to you all!
Sad tidings bring I to you out of France,
Of loss, of slaughter and discomfiture:
Guienne, Champagne, Rheims, Orleans,
Paris, Guysors, Poictiers, are all quite lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: What say'st thou, man, before dead Henry's corse?
Speak softly, or the loss of those great towns
Will make him burst his lead and rise from death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Is Paris lost? is Rouen yielded up?
If Henry were recall'd to life again,
These news would cause him once more yield the ghost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EXETER
SPEECH.LINE: How were they lost? what treachery was used?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: No treachery; but want of men and money.
Amongst the soldiers this is muttered,
That here you maintain several factions,
And whilst a field should be dispatch'd and fought,
You are disputing of your generals:
One would have lingering wars with little cost;
Another would fly swift, but wanteth wings;
A third thinks, without expense at all,
By guileful fair words peace may be obtain'd.
Awake, awake, English nobility!
Let not sloth dim your horrors new-begot:
Cropp'd are the flower-de-luces in your arms;
Of England's coat one half is cut away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EXETER
SPEECH.LINE: Were our tears wanting to this funeral,
These tidings would call forth their flowing tides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Me they concern; Regent I am of France.
Give me my steeled coat. I'll fight for France.
Away with these disgraceful wailing robes!
Wounds will I lend the French instead of eyes,
To weep their intermissive miseries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Lords, view these letters full of bad mischance.
France is revolted from the English quite,
Except some petty towns of no import:
The Dauphin Charles is crowned king of Rheims;
The Bastard of Orleans with him is join'd;
Reignier, Duke of Anjou, doth take his part;
The Duke of Alencon flieth to his side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EXETER
SPEECH.LINE: The Dauphin crowned king! all fly to him!
O, whither shall we fly from this reproach?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: We will not fly, but to our enemies' throats.
Bedford, if thou be slack, I'll fight it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Gloucester, why doubt'st thou of my forwardness?
An army have I muster'd in my thoughts,
Wherewith already France is overrun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious lords, to add to your laments,
Wherewith you now bedew King Henry's hearse,
I must inform you of a dismal fight
Betwixt the stout Lord Talbot and the French.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: What! wherein Talbot overcame? is't so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: O, no; wherein Lord Talbot was o'erthrown:
The circumstance I'll tell you more at large.
The tenth of August last this dreadful lord,
Retiring from the siege of Orleans,
Having full scarce six thousand in his troop.
By three and twenty thousand of the French
Was round encompassed and set upon.
No leisure had he to enrank his men;
He wanted pikes to set before his archers;
Instead whereof sharp stakes pluck'd out of hedges
They pitched in the ground confusedly,
To keep the horsemen off from breaking in.
More than three hours the fight continued;
Where valiant Talbot above human thought
Enacted wonders with his sword and lance:
Hundreds he sent to hell, and none durst stand him;
Here, there, and every where, enraged he flew:
The French exclaim'd, the devil was in arms;
All the whole army stood agazed on him:
His soldiers spying his undaunted spirit
A Talbot! a Talbot! cried out amain
And rush'd into the bowels of the battle.
Here had the conquest fully been seal'd up,
If Sir John Fastolfe had not play'd the coward:
He, being in the vaward, placed behind
With purpose to relieve and follow them,
Cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke.
Hence grew the general wreck and massacre;
Enclosed were they with their enemies:
A base Walloon, to win the Dauphin's grace,
Thrust Talbot with a spear into the back,
Whom all France with their chief assembled strength
Durst not presume to look once in the face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Is Talbot slain? then I will slay myself,
For living idly here in pomp and ease,
Whilst such a worthy leader, wanting aid,
Unto his dastard foemen is betray'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: O no, he lives; but is took prisoner,
And Lord Scales with him and Lord Hungerford:
Most of the rest slaughter'd or took likewise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: His ransom there is none but I shall pay:
I'll hale the Dauphin headlong from his throne:
His crown shall be the ransom of my friend;
Four of their lords I'll change for one of ours.
Farewell, my masters; to my task will I;
Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make,
To keep our great Saint George's feast withal:
Ten thousand soldiers with me I will take,
Whose bloody deeds shall make all Europe quake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: So you had need; for Orleans is besieged;
The English army is grown weak and faint:
The Earl of Salisbury craveth supply,
And hardly keeps his men from mutiny,
Since they, so few, watch such a multitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EXETER
SPEECH.LINE: Remember, lords, your oaths to Henry sworn,
Either to quell the Dauphin utterly,
Or bring him in obedience to your yoke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: I do remember it; and here take my leave,
To go about my preparation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I'll to the Tower with all the haste I can,
To view the artillery and munition;
And then I will proclaim young Henry king.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EXETER
SPEECH.LINE: To Eltham will I, where the young king is,
Being ordain'd his special governor,
And for his safety there I'll best devise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Each hath his place and function to attend:
I am left out; for me nothing remains.
But long I will not be Jack out of office:
The king from Eltham I intend to steal
And sit at chiefest stern of public weal.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. France. Before Orleans.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Sound a flourish. Enter CHARLES, ALENCON, and REIGNIER, marching with drum and Soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Mars his true moving, even as in the heavens
So in the earth, to this day is not known:
Late did he shine upon the English side;
Now we are victors; upon us he smiles.
What towns of any moment but we have?
At pleasure here we lie near Orleans;
Otherwhiles the famish'd English, like pale ghosts,
Faintly besiege us one hour in a month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: They want their porridge and their fat bull-beeves:
Either they must be dieted like mules
And have their provender tied to their mouths
Or piteous they will look, like drowned mice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: Let's raise the siege: why live we idly here?
Talbot is taken, whom we wont to fear:
Remaineth none but mad-brain'd Salisbury;
And he may well in fretting spend his gall,
Nor men nor money hath he to make war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Sound, sound alarum! we will rush on them.
Now for the honour of the forlorn French!
Him I forgive my death that killeth me
When he sees me go back one foot or fly.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here alarum; they are beaten back by the English with great loss. Re-enter CHARLES, ALENCON, and REIGNIER

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Who ever saw the like? what men have I!
Dogs! cowards! dastards! I would ne'er have fled,
But that they left me 'midst my enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: Salisbury is a desperate homicide;
He fighteth as one weary of his life.
The other lords, like lions wanting food,
Do rush upon us as their hungry prey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: Froissart, a countryman of ours, records,
England all Olivers and Rowlands bred,
During the time Edward the Third did reign.
More truly now may this be verified;
For none but Samsons and Goliases
It sendeth forth to skirmish. One to ten!
Lean, raw-boned rascals! who would e'er suppose
They had such courage and audacity?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Let's leave this town; for they are hare-brain'd slaves,
And hunger will enforce them to be more eager:
Of old I know them; rather with their teeth
The walls they'll tear down than forsake the siege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: I think, by some odd gimmors or device
Their arms are set like clocks, stiff to strike on;
Else ne'er could they hold out so as they do.
By my consent, we'll even let them alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: Be it so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
SPEECH.LINE: Where's the Prince Dauphin? I have news for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Bastard of Orleans, thrice welcome to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
SPEECH.LINE: Methinks your looks are sad, your cheer appall'd:
Hath the late overthrow wrought this offence?
Be not dismay'd, for succor is at hand:
A holy maid hither with me I bring,
Which by a vision sent to her from heaven
Ordained is to raise this tedious siege
And drive the English forth the bounds of France.
The spirit of deep prophecy she hath,
Exceeding the nine sibyls of old Rome:
What's past and what's to come she can descry.
Speak, shall I call her in? Believe my words,
For they are certain and unfallible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Go, call her in.
But first, to try her skill,
Reignier, stand thou as Dauphin in my place:
Question her proudly; let thy looks be stern:
By this means shall we sound what skill she hath.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Re-enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, with JOAN LA PUCELLE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: Fair maid, is't thou wilt do these wondrous feats?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Reignier, is't thou that thinkest to beguile me?
Where is the Dauphin? Come, come from behind;
I know thee well, though never seen before.
Be not amazed, there's nothing hid from me:
In private will I talk with thee apart.
Stand back, you lords, and give us leave awhile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: She takes upon her bravely at first dash.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Dauphin, I am by birth a shepherd's daughter,
My wit untrain'd in any kind of art.
Heaven and our Lady gracious hath it pleased
To shine on my contemptible estate:
Lo, whilst I waited on my tender lambs,
And to sun's parching heat display'd my cheeks,
God's mother deigned to appear to me
And in a vision full of majesty
Will'd me to leave my base vocation
And free my country from calamity:
Her aid she promised and assured success:
In complete glory she reveal'd herself;
And, whereas I was black and swart before,
With those clear rays which she infused on me
That beauty am I bless'd with which you see.
Ask me what question thou canst possible,
And I will answer unpremeditated:
My courage try by combat, if thou darest,
And thou shalt find that I exceed my sex.
Resolve on this, thou shalt be fortunate,
If thou receive me for thy warlike mate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast astonish'd me with thy high terms:
Only this proof I'll of thy valour make,
In single combat thou shalt buckle with me,
And if thou vanquishest, thy words are true;
Otherwise I renounce all confidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: I am prepared: here is my keen-edged sword,
Deck'd with five flower-de-luces on each side;
The which at Touraine, in Saint Katharine's
churchyard,
Out of a great deal of old iron I chose forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Then come, o' God's name; I fear no woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: And while I live, I'll ne'er fly from a man.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here they fight, and JOAN LA PUCELLE overcomes

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, stay thy hands! thou art an Amazon
And fightest with the sword of Deborah.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Christ's mother helps me, else I were too weak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Whoe'er helps thee, 'tis thou that must help me:
Impatiently I burn with thy desire;
My heart and hands thou hast at once subdued.
Excellent Pucelle, if thy name be so,
Let me thy servant and not sovereign be:
'Tis the French Dauphin sueth to thee thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: I must not yield to any rites of love,
For my profession's sacred from above:
When I have chased all thy foes from hence,
Then will I think upon a recompense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Meantime look gracious on thy prostrate thrall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, methinks, is very long in talk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: Doubtless he shrives this woman to her smock;
Else ne'er could he so long protract his speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: Shall we disturb him, since he keeps no mean?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: He may mean more than we poor men do know:
These women are shrewd tempters with their tongues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, where are you? what devise you on?
Shall we give over Orleans, or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, no, I say, distrustful recreants!
Fight till the last gasp; I will be your guard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: What she says I'll confirm: we'll fight it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Assign'd am I to be the English scourge.
This night the siege assuredly I'll raise:
Expect Saint Martin's summer, halcyon days,
Since I have entered into these wars.
Glory is like a circle in the water,
Which never ceaseth to enlarge itself
Till by broad spreading it disperse to nought.
With Henry's death the English circle ends;
Dispersed are the glories it included.
Now am I like that proud insulting ship
Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Was Mahomet inspired with a dove?
Thou with an eagle art inspired then.
Helen, the mother of great Constantine,
Nor yet Saint Philip's daughters, were like thee.
Bright star of Venus, fall'n down on the earth,
How may I reverently worship thee enough?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: Leave off delays, and let us raise the siege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: Woman, do what thou canst to save our honours;
Drive them from Orleans and be immortalized.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Presently we'll try: come, let's away about it:
No prophet will I trust, if she prove false.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. London. Before the Tower.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter GLOUCESTER, with his Serving-men in blue coats

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I am come to survey the Tower this day:
Since Henry's death, I fear, there is conveyance.
Where be these warders, that they wait not here?
Open the gates; 'tis Gloucester that calls.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Warder
SPEECH.LINE: Within Who's there that knocks so imperiously?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Serving-Man
SPEECH.LINE: It is the noble Duke of Gloucester.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Warder
SPEECH.LINE: Within Whoe'er he be, you may not be let in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Serving-Man
SPEECH.LINE: Villains, answer you so the lord protector?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Warder
SPEECH.LINE: Within The Lord protect him! so we answer him:
We do no otherwise than we are will'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Who willed you? or whose will stands but mine?
There's none protector of the realm but I.
Break up the gates, I'll be your warrantize.
Shall I be flouted thus by dunghill grooms?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Gloucester's men rush at the Tower Gates, and WOODVILE the Lieutenant speaks within

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WOODVILE
SPEECH.LINE: What noise is this? what traitors have we here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Lieutenant, is it you whose voice I hear?
Open the gates; here's Gloucester that would enter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WOODVILE
SPEECH.LINE: Have patience, noble duke; I may not open;
The Cardinal of Winchester forbids:
From him I have express commandment
That thou nor none of thine shall be let in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Faint-hearted Woodvile, prizest him 'fore me?
Arrogant Winchester, that haughty prelate,
Whom Henry, our late sovereign, ne'er could brook?
Thou art no friend to God or to the king:
Open the gates, or I'll shut thee out shortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Serving-Men
SPEECH.LINE: Open the gates unto the lord protector,
Or we'll burst them open, if that you come not quickly.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter to the Protector at the Tower Gates BISHOP OF WINCHESTER and his men in tawny coats

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: How now, ambitious Humphry! what means this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Peel'd priest, dost thou command me to be shut out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I do, thou most usurping proditor,
And not protector, of the king or realm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Stand back, thou manifest conspirator,
Thou that contrivedst to murder our dead lord;
Thou that givest whores indulgences to sin:
I'll canvass thee in thy broad cardinal's hat,
If thou proceed in this thy insolence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, stand thou back, I will not budge a foot:
This be Damascus, be thou cursed Cain,
To slay thy brother Abel, if thou wilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I will not slay thee, but I'll drive thee back:
Thy scarlet robes as a child's bearing-cloth
I'll use to carry thee out of this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Do what thou darest; I beard thee to thy face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: What! am I dared and bearded to my face?
Draw, men, for all this privileged place;
Blue coats to tawny coats. Priest, beware your beard,
I mean to tug it and to cuff you soundly:
Under my feet I stamp thy cardinal's hat:
In spite of pope or dignities of church,
Here by the cheeks I'll drag thee up and down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Gloucester, thou wilt answer this before the pope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Winchester goose, I cry, a rope! a rope!
Now beat them hence; why do you let them stay?
Thee I'll chase hence, thou wolf in sheep's array.
Out, tawny coats! out, scarlet hypocrite!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here GLOUCESTER's men beat out BISHOP OF WINCHESTER's men, and enter in the hurly- burly the Mayor of London and his Officers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, lords! that you, being supreme magistrates,
Thus contumeliously should break the peace!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, mayor! thou know'st little of my wrongs:
Here's Beaufort, that regards nor God nor king,
Hath here distrain'd the Tower to his use.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Here's Gloucester, a foe to citizens,
One that still motions war and never peace,
O'ercharging your free purses with large fines,
That seeks to overthrow religion,
Because he is protector of the realm,
And would have armour here out of the Tower,
To crown himself king and suppress the prince.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: I will not answer thee with words, but blows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: Naught rests for me in this tumultuous strife
But to make open proclamation:
Come, officer; as loud as e'er thou canst,
Cry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Officer
SPEECH.LINE: All manner of men assembled here in arms this day
against God's peace and the king's, we charge and
command you, in his highness' name, to repair to
your several dwelling-places; and not to wear,
handle, or use any sword, weapon, or dagger,
henceforward, upon pain of death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Cardinal, I'll be no breaker of the law:
But we shall meet, and break our minds at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Gloucester, we will meet; to thy cost, be sure:
Thy heart-blood I will have for this day's work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: I'll call for clubs, if you will not away.
This cardinal's more haughty than the devil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Mayor, farewell: thou dost but what thou mayst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Abominable Gloucester, guard thy head;
For I intend to have it ere long.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt, severally, GLOUCESTER and BISHOP OF WINCHESTER with their Serving-men

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: See the coast clear'd, and then we will depart.
Good God, these nobles should such stomachs bear!
I myself fight not once in forty year.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. Orleans.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter, on the walls, a Master Gunner and his Boy

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Master-Gunner
SPEECH.LINE: Sirrah, thou know'st how Orleans is besieged,
And how the English have the suburbs won.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy
SPEECH.LINE: Father, I know; and oft have shot at them,
Howe'er unfortunate I miss'd my aim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Master-Gunner
SPEECH.LINE: But now thou shalt not. Be thou ruled by me:
Chief master-gunner am I of this town;
Something I must do to procure me grace.
The prince's espials have informed me
How the English, in the suburbs close intrench'd,
Wont, through a secret grate of iron bars
In yonder tower, to overpeer the city,
And thence discover how with most advantage
They may vex us with shot, or with assault.
To intercept this inconvenience,
A piece of ordnance 'gainst it I have placed;
And even these three days have I watch'd,
If I could see them.
Now do thou watch, for I can stay no longer.
If thou spy'st any, run and bring me word;
And thou shalt find me at the governor's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy
SPEECH.LINE: Father, I warrant you; take you no care;
I'll never trouble you, if I may spy them.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter, on the turrets, SALISBURY and TALBOT, GLANSDALE, GARGRAVE, and others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SALISBURY
SPEECH.LINE: Talbot, my life, my joy, again return'd!
How wert thou handled being prisoner?
Or by what means got'st thou to be released?
Discourse, I prithee, on this turret's top.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: The Duke of Bedford had a prisoner
Call'd the brave Lord Ponton de Santrailles;
For him was I exchanged and ransomed.
But with a baser man of arms by far
Once in contempt they would have barter'd me:
Which I, disdaining, scorn'd; and craved death,
Rather than I would be so vile esteem'd.
In fine, redeem'd I was as I desired.
But, O! the treacherous Fastolfe wounds my heart,
Whom with my bare fists I would execute,
If I now had him brought into my power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SALISBURY
SPEECH.LINE: Yet tell'st thou not how thou wert entertain'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: With scoffs and scorns and contumelious taunts.
In open market-place produced they me,
To be a public spectacle to all:
Here, said they, is the terror of the French,
The scarecrow that affrights our children so.
Then broke I from the officers that led me,
And with my nails digg'd stones out of the ground,
To hurl at the beholders of my shame:
My grisly countenance made others fly;
None durst come near for fear of sudden death.
In iron walls they deem'd me not secure;
So great fear of my name 'mongst them was spread,
That they supposed I could rend bars of steel,
And spurn in pieces posts of adamant:
Wherefore a guard of chosen shot I had,
That walked about me every minute-while;
And if I did but stir out of my bed,
Ready they were to shoot me to the heart.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Boy with a linstock

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SALISBURY
SPEECH.LINE: I grieve to hear what torments you endured,
But we will be revenged sufficiently
Now it is supper-time in Orleans:
Here, through this grate, I count each one
and view the Frenchmen how they fortify:
Let us look in; the sight will much delight thee.
Sir Thomas Gargrave, and Sir William Glansdale,
Let me have your express opinions
Where is best place to make our battery next.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GARGRAVE
SPEECH.LINE: I think, at the north gate; for there stand lords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLANSDALE
SPEECH.LINE: And I, here, at the bulwark of the bridge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: For aught I see, this city must be famish'd,
Or with light skirmishes enfeebled.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here they shoot. SALISBURY and GARGRAVE fall

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SALISBURY
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord, have mercy on us, wretched sinners!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GARGRAVE
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord, have mercy on me, woful man!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: What chance is this that suddenly hath cross'd us?
Speak, Salisbury; at least, if thou canst speak:
How farest thou, mirror of all martial men?
One of thy eyes and thy cheek's side struck off!
Accursed tower! accursed fatal hand
That hath contrived this woful tragedy!
In thirteen battles Salisbury o'ercame;
Henry the Fifth he first train'd to the wars;
Whilst any trump did sound, or drum struck up,
His sword did ne'er leave striking in the field.
Yet livest thou, Salisbury? though thy speech doth fail,
One eye thou hast, to look to heaven for grace:
The sun with one eye vieweth all the world.
Heaven, be thou gracious to none alive,
If Salisbury wants mercy at thy hands!
Bear hence his body; I will help to bury it.
Sir Thomas Gargrave, hast thou any life?
Speak unto Talbot; nay, look up to him.
Salisbury, cheer thy spirit with this comfort;
Thou shalt not die whiles--
He beckons with his hand and smiles on me.
As who should say 'When I am dead and gone,
Remember to avenge me on the French.'
Plantagenet, I will; and like thee, Nero,
Play on the lute, beholding the towns burn:
Wretched shall France be only in my name.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Here an alarum, and it thunders and lightens
SPEECH.LINE: What stir is this? what tumult's in the heavens?
Whence cometh this alarum and the noise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, my lord, the French have gathered head:
The Dauphin, with one Joan la Pucelle join'd,
A holy prophetess new risen up,
Is come with a great power to raise the siege.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here SALISBURY lifteth himself up and groans

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Hear, hear how dying Salisbury doth groan!
It irks his heart he cannot be revenged.
Frenchmen, I'll be a Salisbury to you:
Pucelle or puzzel, dolphin or dogfish,
Your hearts I'll stamp out with my horse's heels,
And make a quagmire of your mingled brains.
Convey me Salisbury into his tent,
And then we'll try what these dastard Frenchmen dare.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE V. The same.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here an alarum again: and TALBOT pursueth the DAUPHIN, and driveth him: then enter JOAN LA PUCELLE, driving Englishmen before her, and exit after them then re-enter TALBOT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Where is my strength, my valour, and my force?
Our English troops retire, I cannot stay them:
A woman clad in armour chaseth them.
Here, here she comes. I'll have a bout with thee;
Devil or devil's dam, I'll conjure thee:
Blood will I draw on thee, thou art a witch,
And straightway give thy soul to him thou servest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, 'tis only I that must disgrace thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Heavens, can you suffer hell so to prevail?
My breast I'll burst with straining of my courage
And from my shoulders crack my arms asunder.
But I will chastise this high-minded strumpet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Talbot, farewell; thy hour is not yet come:
I must go victual Orleans forthwith.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: A short alarum; then enter the town with soldiers
SPEECH.LINE: O'ertake me, if thou canst; I scorn thy strength.
Go, go, cheer up thy hungry-starved men;
Help Salisbury to make his testament:
This day is ours, as many more shall be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: My thoughts are whirled like a potter's wheel;
I know not where I am, nor what I do;
A witch, by fear, not force, like Hannibal,
Drives back our troops and conquers as she lists:
So bees with smoke and doves with noisome stench
Are from their hives and houses driven away.
They call'd us for our fierceness English dogs;
Now, like to whelps, we crying run away.
Hark, countrymen! either renew the fight,
Or tear the lions out of England's coat;
Renounce your soil, give sheep in lions' stead:
Sheep run not half so treacherous from the wolf,
Or horse or oxen from the leopard,
As you fly from your oft-subdued slaves.
It will not be: retire into your trenches:
You all consented unto Salisbury's death,
For none would strike a stroke in his revenge.
Pucelle is enter'd into Orleans,
In spite of us or aught that we could do.
O, would I were to die with Salisbury!
The shame hereof will make me hide my head.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE VI. The same.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter, on the walls, JOAN LA PUCELLE, CHARLES, REIGNIER, ALENCON, and Soldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Advance our waving colours on the walls;
Rescued is Orleans from the English
Thus Joan la Pucelle hath perform'd her word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Divinest creature, Astraea's daughter,
How shall I honour thee for this success?
Thy promises are like Adonis' gardens
That one day bloom'd and fruitful were the next.
France, triumph in thy glorious prophetess!
Recover'd is the town of Orleans:
More blessed hap did ne'er befall our state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: Why ring not out the bells aloud throughout the town?
Dauphin, command the citizens make bonfires
And feast and banquet in the open streets,
To celebrate the joy that God hath given us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: All France will be replete with mirth and joy,
When they shall hear how we have play'd the men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis Joan, not we, by whom the day is won;
For which I will divide my crown with her,
And all the priests and friars in my realm
Shall in procession sing her endless praise.
A statelier pyramis to her I'll rear
Than Rhodope's or Memphis' ever was:
In memory of her when she is dead,
Her ashes, in an urn more precious
Than the rich-jewel'd of Darius,
Transported shall be at high festivals
Before the kings and queens of France.
No longer on Saint Denis will we cry,
But Joan la Pucelle shall be France's saint.
Come in, and let us banquet royally,
After this golden day of victory.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Before Orleans.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a Sergeant of a band with two Sentinels

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sergeant
SPEECH.LINE: Sirs, take your places and be vigilant:
If any noise or soldier you perceive
Near to the walls, by some apparent sign
Let us have knowledge at the court of guard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Sentinel
SPEECH.LINE: Sergeant, you shall.
Thus are poor servitors,
When others sleep upon their quiet beds,
Constrain'd to watch in darkness, rain and cold.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter TALBOT, BEDFORD, BURGUNDY, and Forces, with scaling-ladders, their drums beating a dead march

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy,
By whose approach the regions of Artois,
Wallon and Picardy are friends to us,
This happy night the Frenchmen are secure,
Having all day caroused and banqueted:
Embrace we then this opportunity
As fitting best to quittance their deceit
Contrived by art and baleful sorcery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Coward of France! how much he wrongs his fame,
Despairing of his own arm's fortitude,
To join with witches and the help of hell!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BURGUNDY
SPEECH.LINE: Traitors have never other company.
But what's that Pucelle whom they term so pure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: A maid, they say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: A maid! and be so martial!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BURGUNDY
SPEECH.LINE: Pray God she prove not masculine ere long,
If underneath the standard of the French
She carry armour as she hath begun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Well, let them practise and converse with spirits:
God is our fortress, in whose conquering name
Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Ascend, brave Talbot; we will follow thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Not all together: better far, I guess,
That we do make our entrance several ways;
That, if it chance the one of us do fail,
The other yet may rise against their force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Agreed: I'll to yond corner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BURGUNDY
SPEECH.LINE: And I to this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: And here will Talbot mount, or make his grave.
Now, Salisbury, for thee, and for the right
Of English Henry, shall this night appear
How much in duty I am bound to both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sentinels
SPEECH.LINE: Arm! arm! the enemy doth make assault!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: The French leap over the walls in their shirts. Enter, several ways, the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, and REIGNIER, half ready, and half unready

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: How now, my lords! what, all unready so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
SPEECH.LINE: Unready! ay, and glad we 'scaped so well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas time, I trow, to wake and leave our beds,
Hearing alarums at our chamber-doors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: Of all exploits since first I follow'd arms,
Ne'er heard I of a warlike enterprise
More venturous or desperate than this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
SPEECH.LINE: I think this Talbot be a fiend of hell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: If not of hell, the heavens, sure, favour him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: Here cometh Charles: I marvel how he sped.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, holy Joan was his defensive guard.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter CHARLES and JOAN LA PUCELLE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Is this thy cunning, thou deceitful dame?
Didst thou at first, to flatter us withal,
Make us partakers of a little gain,
That now our loss might be ten times so much?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend!
At all times will you have my power alike?
Sleeping or waking must I still prevail,
Or will you blame and lay the fault on me?
Improvident soldiers! had your watch been good,
This sudden mischief never could have fall'n.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Duke of Alencon, this was your default,
That, being captain of the watch to-night,
Did look no better to that weighty charge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: Had all your quarters been as safely kept
As that whereof I had the government,
We had not been thus shamefully surprised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
SPEECH.LINE: Mine was secure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: And so was mine, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: And, for myself, most part of all this night,
Within her quarter and mine own precinct
I was employ'd in passing to and fro,
About relieving of the sentinels:
Then how or which way should they first break in?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Question, my lords, no further of the case,
How or which way: 'tis sure they found some place
But weakly guarded, where the breach was made.
And now there rests no other shift but this;
To gather our soldiers, scatter'd and dispersed,
And lay new platforms to endamage them.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum. Enter an English Soldier, crying 'A Talbot! a Talbot!' They fly, leaving their clothes behind

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: I'll be so bold to take what they have left.
The cry of Talbot serves me for a sword;
For I have loaden me with many spoils,
Using no other weapon but his name.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. Orleans. Within the town.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter TALBOT, BEDFORD, BURGUNDY, a Captain, and others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: The day begins to break, and night is fled,
Whose pitchy mantle over-veil'd the earth.
Here sound retreat, and cease our hot pursuit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Bring forth the body of old Salisbury,
And here advance it in the market-place,
The middle centre of this cursed town.
Now have I paid my vow unto his soul;
For every drop of blood was drawn from him,
There hath at least five Frenchmen died tonight.
And that hereafter ages may behold
What ruin happen'd in revenge of him,
Within their chiefest temple I'll erect
A tomb, wherein his corpse shall be interr'd:
Upon the which, that every one may read,
Shall be engraved the sack of Orleans,
The treacherous manner of his mournful death
And what a terror he had been to France.
But, lords, in all our bloody massacre,
I muse we met not with the Dauphin's grace,
His new-come champion, virtuous Joan of Arc,
Nor any of his false confederates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis thought, Lord Talbot, when the fight began,
Roused on the sudden from their drowsy beds,
They did amongst the troops of armed men
Leap o'er the walls for refuge in the field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BURGUNDY
SPEECH.LINE: Myself, as far as I could well discern
For smoke and dusky vapours of the night,
Am sure I scared the Dauphin and his trull,
When arm in arm they both came swiftly running,
Like to a pair of loving turtle-doves
That could not live asunder day or night.
After that things are set in order here,
We'll follow them with all the power we have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: All hail, my lords! which of this princely train
Call ye the warlike Talbot, for his acts
So much applauded through the realm of France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Here is the Talbot: who would speak with him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: The virtuous lady, Countess of Auvergne,
With modesty admiring thy renown,
By me entreats, great lord, thou wouldst vouchsafe
To visit her poor castle where she lies,
That she may boast she hath beheld the man
Whose glory fills the world with loud report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BURGUNDY
SPEECH.LINE: Is it even so? Nay, then, I see our wars
Will turn unto a peaceful comic sport,
When ladies crave to be encounter'd with.
You may not, my lord, despise her gentle suit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Ne'er trust me then; for when a world of men
Could not prevail with all their oratory,
Yet hath a woman's kindness over-ruled:
And therefore tell her I return great thanks,
And in submission will attend on her.
Will not your honours bear me company?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: No, truly; it is more than manners will:
And I have heard it said, unbidden guests
Are often welcomest when they are gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Well then, alone, since there's no remedy,
I mean to prove this lady's courtesy.
Come hither, captain.
You perceive my mind?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Captain
SPEECH.LINE: I do, my lord, and mean accordingly.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. Auvergne. The COUNTESS's castle.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the COUNTESS and her Porter

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: Porter, remember what I gave in charge;
And when you have done so, bring the keys to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: The plot is laid: if all things fall out right,
I shall as famous be by this exploit
As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus' death.
Great is the rumor of this dreadful knight,
And his achievements of no less account:
Fain would mine eyes be witness with mine ears,
To give their censure of these rare reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Madam,
According as your ladyship desired,
By message craved, so is Lord Talbot come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: And he is welcome. What! is this the man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: Is this the scourge of France?
Is this the Talbot, so much fear'd abroad
That with his name the mothers still their babes?
I see report is fabulous and false:
I thought I should have seen some Hercules,
A second Hector, for his grim aspect,
And large proportion of his strong-knit limbs.
Alas, this is a child, a silly dwarf!
It cannot be this weak and writhled shrimp
Should strike such terror to his enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I have been bold to trouble you;
But since your ladyship is not at leisure,
I'll sort some other time to visit you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: What means he now? Go ask him whither he goes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messenger
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, my Lord Talbot; for my lady craves
To know the cause of your abrupt departure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, for that she's in a wrong belief,
I go to certify her Talbot's here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: If thou be he, then art thou prisoner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Prisoner! to whom?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: To me, blood-thirsty lord;
And for that cause I trained thee to my house.
Long time thy shadow hath been thrall to me,
For in my gallery thy picture hangs:
But now the substance shall endure the like,
And I will chain these legs and arms of thine,
That hast by tyranny these many years
Wasted our country, slain our citizens
And sent our sons and husbands captivate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha, ha!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: Laughest thou, wretch? thy mirth shall turn to moan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: I laugh to see your ladyship so fond
To think that you have aught but Talbot's shadow
Whereon to practise your severity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: Why, art not thou the man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: I am indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: Then have I substance too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, I am but shadow of myself:
You are deceived, my substance is not here;
For what you see is but the smallest part
And least proportion of humanity:
I tell you, madam, were the whole frame here,
It is of such a spacious lofty pitch,
Your roof were not sufficient to contain't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: This is a riddling merchant for the nonce;
He will be here, and yet he is not here:
How can these contrarieties agree?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: That will I show you presently.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Winds his horn. Drums strike up: a peal of ordnance. Enter soldiers
SPEECH.LINE: How say you, madam? are you now persuaded
That Talbot is but shadow of himself?
These are his substance, sinews, arms and strength,
With which he yoketh your rebellious necks,
Razeth your cities and subverts your towns
And in a moment makes them desolate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: Victorious Talbot! pardon my abuse:
I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited
And more than may be gather'd by thy shape.
Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath;
For I am sorry that with reverence
I did not entertain thee as thou art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Be not dismay'd, fair lady; nor misconstrue
The mind of Talbot, as you did mistake
The outward composition of his body.
What you have done hath not offended me;
Nor other satisfaction do I crave,
But only, with your patience, that we may
Taste of your wine and see what cates you have;
For soldiers' stomachs always serve them well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart, and think me honoured
To feast so great a warrior in my house.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. London. The Temple-garden.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Earls of SOMERSET, SUFFOLK, and WARWICK; RICHARD PLANTAGENET, VERNON, and another Lawyer

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Great lords and gentlemen, what means this silence?
Dare no man answer in a case of truth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SUFFOLK
SPEECH.LINE: Within the Temple-hall we were too loud;
The garden here is more convenient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Then say at once if I maintain'd the truth;
Or else was wrangling Somerset in the error?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SUFFOLK
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, I have been a truant in the law,
And never yet could frame my will to it;
And therefore frame the law unto my will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Judge you, my Lord of Warwick, then, between us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Between two hawks, which flies the higher pitch;
Between two dogs, which hath the deeper mouth;
Between two blades, which bears the better temper:
Between two horses, which doth bear him best;
Between two girls, which hath the merriest eye;
I have perhaps some shallow spirit of judgement;
But in these nice sharp quillets of the law,
Good faith, I am no wiser than a daw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, tut, here is a mannerly forbearance:
The truth appears so naked on my side
That any purblind eye may find it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: And on my side it is so well apparell'd,
So clear, so shining and so evident
That it will glimmer through a blind man's eye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Since you are tongue-tied and so loath to speak,
In dumb significants proclaim your thoughts:
Let him that is a true-born gentleman
And stands upon the honour of his birth,
If he suppose that I have pleaded truth,
From off this brier pluck a white rose with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Let him that is no coward nor no flatterer,
But dare maintain the party of the truth,
Pluck a red rose from off this thorn with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: I love no colours, and without all colour
Of base insinuating flattery
I pluck this white rose with Plantagenet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SUFFOLK
SPEECH.LINE: I pluck this red rose with young Somerset
And say withal I think he held the right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VERNON
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, lords and gentlemen, and pluck no more,
Till you conclude that he upon whose side
The fewest roses are cropp'd from the tree
Shall yield the other in the right opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Good Master Vernon, it is well objected:
If I have fewest, I subscribe in silence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: And I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VERNON
SPEECH.LINE: Then for the truth and plainness of the case.
I pluck this pale and maiden blossom here,
Giving my verdict on the white rose side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Prick not your finger as you pluck it off,
Lest bleeding you do paint the white rose red
And fall on my side so, against your will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VERNON
SPEECH.LINE: If I my lord, for my opinion bleed,
Opinion shall be surgeon to my hurt
And keep me on the side where still I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, come on: who else?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawyer
SPEECH.LINE: Unless my study and my books be false,
The argument you held was wrong in you:
In sign whereof I pluck a white rose too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Now, Somerset, where is your argument?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Here in my scabbard, meditating that
Shall dye your white rose in a bloody red.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Meantime your cheeks do counterfeit our roses;
For pale they look with fear, as witnessing
The truth on our side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: No, Plantagenet,
'Tis not for fear but anger that thy cheeks
Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses,
And yet thy tongue will not confess thy error.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Hath not thy rose a canker, Somerset?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Hath not thy rose a thorn, Plantagenet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, sharp and piercing, to maintain his truth;
Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falsehood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I'll find friends to wear my bleeding roses,
That shall maintain what I have said is true,
Where false Plantagenet dare not be seen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Now, by this maiden blossom in my hand,
I scorn thee and thy fashion, peevish boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SUFFOLK
SPEECH.LINE: Turn not thy scorns this way, Plantagenet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Proud Pole, I will, and scorn both him and thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SUFFOLK
SPEECH.LINE: I'll turn my part thereof into thy throat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Away, away, good William de la Pole!
We grace the yeoman by conversing with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Now, by God's will, thou wrong'st him, Somerset;
His grandfather was Lionel Duke of Clarence,
Third son to the third Edward King of England:
Spring crestless yeomen from so deep a root?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: He bears him on the place's privilege,
Or durst not, for his craven heart, say thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: By him that made me, I'll maintain my words
On any plot of ground in Christendom.
Was not thy father, Richard Earl of Cambridge,
For treason executed in our late king's days?
And, by his treason, stand'st not thou attainted,
Corrupted, and exempt from ancient gentry?
His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood;
And, till thou be restored, thou art a yeoman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: My father was attached, not attainted,
Condemn'd to die for treason, but no traitor;
And that I'll prove on better men than Somerset,
Were growing time once ripen'd to my will.
For your partaker Pole and you yourself,
I'll note you in my book of memory,
To scourge you for this apprehension:
Look to it well and say you are well warn'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, thou shalt find us ready for thee still;
And know us by these colours for thy foes,
For these my friends in spite of thee shall wear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: And, by my soul, this pale and angry rose,
As cognizance of my blood-drinking hate,
Will I for ever and my faction wear,
Until it wither with me to my grave
Or flourish to the height of my degree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SUFFOLK
SPEECH.LINE: Go forward and be choked with thy ambition!
And so farewell until I meet thee next.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Have with thee, Pole. Farewell, ambitious Richard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: How I am braved and must perforce endure it!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: This blot that they object against your house
Shall be wiped out in the next parliament
Call'd for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester;
And if thou be not then created York,
I will not live to be accounted Warwick.
Meantime, in signal of my love to thee,
Against proud Somerset and William Pole,
Will I upon thy party wear this rose:
And here I prophesy: this brawl to-day,
Grown to this faction in the Temple-garden,
Shall send between the red rose and the white
A thousand souls to death and deadly night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Good Master Vernon, I am bound to you,
That you on my behalf would pluck a flower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VERNON
SPEECH.LINE: In your behalf still will I wear the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawyer
SPEECH.LINE: And so will I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Thanks, gentle sir.
Come, let us four to dinner: I dare say
This quarrel will drink blood another day.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE V. The Tower of London.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter MORTIMER, brought in a chair, and Gaolers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MORTIMER
SPEECH.LINE: Kind keepers of my weak decaying age,
Let dying Mortimer here rest himself.
Even like a man new haled from the rack,
So fare my limbs with long imprisonment.
And these grey locks, the pursuivants of death,
Nestor-like aged in an age of care,
Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer.
These eyes, like lamps whose wasting oil is spent,
Wax dim, as drawing to their exigent;
Weak shoulders, overborne with burthening grief,
And pithless arms, like to a wither'd vine
That droops his sapless branches to the ground;
Yet are these feet, whose strengthless stay is numb,
Unable to support this lump of clay,
Swift-winged with desire to get a grave,
As witting I no other comfort have.
But tell me, keeper, will my nephew come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Gaoler
SPEECH.LINE: Richard Plantagenet, my lord, will come:
We sent unto the Temple, unto his chamber;
And answer was return'd that he will come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MORTIMER
SPEECH.LINE: Enough: my soul shall then be satisfied.
Poor gentleman! his wrong doth equal mine.
Since Henry Monmouth first began to reign,
Before whose glory I was great in arms,
This loathsome sequestration have I had:
And even since then hath Richard been obscured,
Deprived of honour and inheritance.
But now the arbitrator of despairs,
Just death, kind umpire of men's miseries,
With sweet enlargement doth dismiss me hence:
I would his troubles likewise were expired,
That so he might recover what was lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Gaoler
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, your loving nephew now is come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MORTIMER
SPEECH.LINE: Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, noble uncle, thus ignobly used,
Your nephew, late despised Richard, comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MORTIMER
SPEECH.LINE: Direct mine arms I may embrace his neck,
And in his bosom spend my latter gasp:
O, tell me when my lips do touch his cheeks,
That I may kindly give one fainting kiss.
And now declare, sweet stem from York's great stock,
Why didst thou say, of late thou wert despised?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: First, lean thine aged back against mine arm;
And, in that ease, I'll tell thee my disease.
This day, in argument upon a case,
Some words there grew 'twixt Somerset and me;
Among which terms he used his lavish tongue
And did upbraid me with my father's death:
Which obloquy set bars before my tongue,
Else with the like I had requited him.
Therefore, good uncle, for my father's sake,
In honour of a true Plantagenet
And for alliance sake, declare the cause
My father, Earl of Cambridge, lost his head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MORTIMER
SPEECH.LINE: That cause, fair nephew, that imprison'd me
And hath detain'd me all my flowering youth
Within a loathsome dungeon, there to pine,
Was cursed instrument of his decease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Discover more at large what cause that was,
For I am ignorant and cannot guess.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MORTIMER
SPEECH.LINE: I will, if that my fading breath permit
And death approach not ere my tale be done.
Henry the Fourth, grandfather to this king,
Deposed his nephew Richard, Edward's son,
The first-begotten and the lawful heir,
Of Edward king, the third of that descent:
During whose reign the Percies of the north,
Finding his usurpation most unjust,
Endeavor'd my advancement to the throne:
The reason moved these warlike lords to this
Was, for that--young King Richard thus removed,
Leaving no heir begotten of his body--
I was the next by birth and parentage;
For by my mother I derived am
From Lionel Duke of Clarence, the third son
To King Edward the Third; whereas he
From John of Gaunt doth bring his pedigree,
Being but fourth of that heroic line.
But mark: as in this haughty attempt
They laboured to plant the rightful heir,
I lost my liberty and they their lives.
Long after this, when Henry the Fifth,
Succeeding his father Bolingbroke, did reign,
Thy father, Earl of Cambridge, then derived
From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of York,
Marrying my sister that thy mother was,
Again in pity of my hard distress
Levied an army, weening to redeem
And have install'd me in the diadem:
But, as the rest, so fell that noble earl
And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers,
In whom the tide rested, were suppress'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Of which, my lord, your honour is the last.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MORTIMER
SPEECH.LINE: True; and thou seest that I no issue have
And that my fainting words do warrant death;
Thou art my heir; the rest I wish thee gather:
But yet be wary in thy studious care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Thy grave admonishments prevail with me:
But yet, methinks, my father's execution
Was nothing less than bloody tyranny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MORTIMER
SPEECH.LINE: With silence, nephew, be thou politic:
Strong-fixed is the house of Lancaster,
And like a mountain, not to be removed.
But now thy uncle is removing hence:
As princes do their courts, when they are cloy'd
With long continuance in a settled place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: O, uncle, would some part of my young years
Might but redeem the passage of your age!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MORTIMER
SPEECH.LINE: Thou dost then wrong me, as that slaughterer doth
Which giveth many wounds when one will kill.
Mourn not, except thou sorrow for my good;
Only give order for my funeral:
And so farewell, and fair be all thy hopes
And prosperous be thy life in peace and war!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: And peace, no war, befall thy parting soul!
In prison hast thou spent a pilgrimage
And like a hermit overpass'd thy days.
Well, I will lock his counsel in my breast;
And what I do imagine let that rest.
Keepers, convey him hence, and I myself
Will see his burial better than his life.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Exeunt Gaolers, bearing out the body of MORTIMER
SPEECH.LINE: Here dies the dusky torch of Mortimer,
Choked with ambition of the meaner sort:
And for those wrongs, those bitter injuries,
Which Somerset hath offer'd to my house:
I doubt not but with honour to redress;
And therefore haste I to the parliament,
Either to be restored to my blood,
Or make my ill the advantage of my good.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. London. The Parliament-house.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, EXETER, GLOUCESTER, WARWICK, SOMERSET, and SUFFOLK; the BISHOP OF WINCHESTER, RICHARD PLANTAGENET, and others. GLOUCESTER offers to put up a bill; BISHOP OF WINCHESTER snatches it, and tears it

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Comest thou with deep premeditated lines,
With written pamphlets studiously devised,
Humphrey of Gloucester? If thou canst accuse,
Or aught intend'st to lay unto my charge,
Do it without invention, suddenly;
As I with sudden and extemporal speech
Purpose to answer what thou canst object.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Presumptuous priest! this place commands my patience,
Or thou shouldst find thou hast dishonour'd me.
Think not, although in writing I preferr'd
The manner of thy vile outrageous crimes,
That therefore I have forged, or am not able
Verbatim to rehearse the method of my pen:
No, prelate; such is thy audacious wickedness,
Thy lewd, pestiferous and dissentious pranks,
As very infants prattle of thy pride.
Thou art a most pernicious usurer,
Forward by nature, enemy to peace;
Lascivious, wanton, more than well beseems
A man of thy profession and degree;
And for thy treachery, what's more manifest?
In that thou laid'st a trap to take my life,
As well at London bridge as at the Tower.
Beside, I fear me, if thy thoughts were sifted,
The king, thy sovereign, is not quite exempt
From envious malice of thy swelling heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Gloucester, I do defy thee. Lords, vouchsafe
To give me hearing what I shall reply.
If I were covetous, ambitious or perverse,
As he will have me, how am I so poor?
Or how haps it I seek not to advance
Or raise myself, but keep my wonted calling?
And for dissension, who preferreth peace
More than I do?--except I be provoked.
No, my good lords, it is not that offends;
It is not that that hath incensed the duke:
It is, because no one should sway but he;
No one but he should be about the king;
And that engenders thunder in his breast
And makes him roar these accusations forth.
But he shall know I am as good--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: As good!
Thou bastard of my grandfather!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, lordly sir; for what are you, I pray,
But one imperious in another's throne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Am I not protector, saucy priest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: And am not I a prelate of the church?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, as an outlaw in a castle keeps
And useth it to patronage his theft.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Unreverent Gloster!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art reverent
Touching thy spiritual function, not thy life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Rome shall remedy this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Roam thither, then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, it were your duty to forbear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, see the bishop be not overborne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Methinks my lord should be religious
And know the office that belongs to such.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Methinks his lordship should be humbler;
it fitteth not a prelate so to plead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, when his holy state is touch'd so near.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: State holy or unhallow'd, what of that?
Is not his grace protector to the king?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Aside Plantagenet, I see, must hold his tongue,
Lest it be said 'Speak, sirrah, when you should;
Must your bold verdict enter talk with lords?'
Else would I have a fling at Winchester.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Uncles of Gloucester and of Winchester,
The special watchmen of our English weal,
I would prevail, if prayers might prevail,
To join your hearts in love and amity.
O, what a scandal is it to our crown,
That two such noble peers as ye should jar!
Believe me, lords, my tender years can tell
Civil dissension is a viperous worm
That gnaws the bowels of the commonwealth.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: A noise within, 'Down with the tawny-coats!'
SPEECH.LINE: What tumult's this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: An uproar, I dare warrant,
Begun through malice of the bishop's men.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A noise again, 'Stones! stones!' Enter Mayor

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayor
SPEECH.LINE: O, my good lords, and virtuous Henry,
Pity the city of London, pity us!
The bishop and the Duke of Gloucester's men,
Forbidden late to carry any weapon,
Have fill'd their pockets full of pebble stones
And banding themselves in contrary parts
Do pelt so fast at one another's pate
That many have their giddy brains knock'd out:
Our windows are broke down in every street
And we for fear compell'd to shut our shops.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Serving-men, in skirmish, with bloody pates

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: We charge you, on allegiance to ourself,
To hold your slaughtering hands and keep the peace.
Pray, uncle Gloucester, mitigate this strife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Serving-man
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if we be forbidden stones,
We'll fall to it with our teeth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Serving-man
SPEECH.LINE: Do what ye dare, we are as resolute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: You of my household, leave this peevish broil
And set this unaccustom'd fight aside.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Serving-man
SPEECH.LINE: My lord, we know your grace to be a man
Just and upright; and, for your royal birth,
Inferior to none but to his majesty:
And ere that we will suffer such a prince,
So kind a father of the commonweal,
To be disgraced by an inkhorn mate,
We and our wives and children all will fight
And have our bodies slaughtered by thy foes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Serving-man
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, and the very parings of our nails
Shall pitch a field when we are dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, stay, I say!
And if you love me, as you say you do,
Let me persuade you to forbear awhile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: O, how this discord doth afflict my soul!
Can you, my Lord of Winchester, behold
My sighs and tears and will not once relent?
Who should be pitiful, if you be not?
Or who should study to prefer a peace.
If holy churchmen take delight in broils?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Yield, my lord protector; yield, Winchester;
Except you mean with obstinate repulse
To slay your sovereign and destroy the realm.
You see what mischief and what murder too
Hath been enacted through your enmity;
Then be at peace except ye thirst for blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: He shall submit, or I will never yield.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Compassion on the king commands me stoop;
Or I would see his heart out, ere the priest
Should ever get that privilege of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Behold, my Lord of Winchester, the duke
Hath banish'd moody discontented fury,
As by his smoothed brows it doth appear:
Why look you still so stern and tragical?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Here, Winchester, I offer thee my hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, uncle Beaufort! I have heard you preach
That malice was a great and grievous sin;
And will not you maintain the thing you teach,
But prove a chief offender in the same?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet king! the bishop hath a kindly gird.
For shame, my lord of Winchester, relent!
What, shall a child instruct you what to do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Well, Duke of Gloucester, I will yield to thee;
Love for thy love and hand for hand I give.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside Ay, but, I fear me, with a hollow heart.--
See here, my friends and loving countrymen,
This token serveth for a flag of truce
Betwixt ourselves and all our followers:
So help me God, as I dissemble not!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Aside So help me God, as I intend it not!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: O, loving uncle, kind Duke of Gloucester,
How joyful am I made by this contract!
Away, my masters! trouble us no more;
But join in friendship, as your lords have done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Serving-man
SPEECH.LINE: Content: I'll to the surgeon's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Serving-man
SPEECH.LINE: And so will I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Third Serving-man
SPEECH.LINE: And I will see what physic the tavern affords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Accept this scroll, most gracious sovereign,
Which in the right of Richard Plantagenet
We do exhibit to your majesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Well urged, my Lord of Warwick: or sweet prince,
And if your grace mark every circumstance,
You have great reason to do Richard right;
Especially for those occasions
At Eltham Place I told your majesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: And those occasions, uncle, were of force:
Therefore, my loving lords, our pleasure is
That Richard be restored to his blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WARWICK
SPEECH.LINE: Let Richard be restored to his blood;
So shall his father's wrongs be recompensed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BISHOP OF WINCHESTER
SPEECH.LINE: As will the rest, so willeth Winchester.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: If Richard will be true, not that alone
But all the whole inheritance I give
That doth belong unto the house of York,
From whence you spring by lineal descent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: Thy humble servant vows obedience
And humble service till the point of death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: Stoop then and set your knee against my foot;
And, in reguerdon of that duty done,
I gird thee with the valiant sword of York:
Rise Richard, like a true Plantagenet,
And rise created princely Duke of York.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
SPEECH.LINE: And so thrive Richard as thy foes may fall!
And as my duty springs, so perish they
That grudge one thought against your majesty!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALL
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, high prince, the mighty Duke of York!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SOMERSET
SPEECH.LINE: Aside Perish, base prince, ignoble Duke of York!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Now will it best avail your majesty
To cross the seas and to be crown'd in France:
The presence of a king engenders love
Amongst his subjects and his loyal friends,
As it disanimates his enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KING HENRY VI
SPEECH.LINE: When Gloucester says the word, King Henry goes;
For friendly counsel cuts off many foes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GLOUCESTER
SPEECH.LINE: Your ships already are in readiness.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Sennet. Flourish. Exeunt all but EXETER

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EXETER
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, we may march in England or in France,
Not seeing what is likely to ensue.
This late dissension grown betwixt the peers
Burns under feigned ashes of forged love
And will at last break out into a flame:
As fester'd members rot but by degree,
Till bones and flesh and sinews fall away,
So will this base and envious discord breed.
And now I fear that fatal prophecy
Which in the time of Henry named the Fifth
Was in the mouth of every sucking babe;
That Henry born at Monmouth should win all
And Henry born at Windsor lose all:
Which is so plain that Exeter doth wish
His days may finish ere that hapless time.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE II. France. Before Rouen.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE disguised, with four Soldiers with sacks upon their backs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: These are the city gates, the gates of Rouen,
Through which our policy must make a breach:
Take heed, be wary how you place your words;
Talk like the vulgar sort of market men
That come to gather money for their corn.
If we have entrance, as I hope we shall,
And that we find the slothful watch but weak,
I'll by a sign give notice to our friends,
That Charles the Dauphin may encounter them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Soldier
SPEECH.LINE: Our sacks shall be a mean to sack the city,
And we be lords and rulers over Rouen;
Therefore we'll knock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch
SPEECH.LINE: Within Qui est la?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Paysans, pauvres gens de France;
Poor market folks that come to sell their corn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch
SPEECH.LINE: Enter, go in; the market bell is rung.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Now, Rouen, I'll shake thy bulwarks to the ground.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter CHARLES, the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, REIGNIER, and forces

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Saint Denis bless this happy stratagem!
And once again we'll sleep secure in Rouen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
SPEECH.LINE: Here enter'd Pucelle and her practisants;
Now she is there, how will she specify
Where is the best and safest passage in?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: By thrusting out a torch from yonder tower;
Which, once discern'd, shows that her meaning is,
No way to that, for weakness, which she enter'd.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE on the top, thrusting out a torch burning

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Behold, this is the happy wedding torch
That joineth Rouen unto her countrymen,
But burning fatal to the Talbotites!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
SPEECH.LINE: See, noble Charles, the beacon of our friend;
The burning torch in yonder turret stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Now shine it like a comet of revenge,
A prophet to the fall of all our foes!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REIGNIER
SPEECH.LINE: Defer no time, delays have dangerous ends;
Enter, and cry 'The Dauphin!' presently,
And then do execution on the watch.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: An alarum. Enter TALBOT in an excursion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: France, thou shalt rue this treason with thy tears,
If Talbot but survive thy treachery.
Pucelle, that witch, that damned sorceress,
Hath wrought this hellish mischief unawares,
That hardly we escaped the pride of France.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: An alarum: excursions. BEDFORD, brought in sick in a chair. Enter TALBOT and BURGUNDY without: within JOAN LA PUCELLE, CHARLES, BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, and REIGNIER, on the walls

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, gallants! want ye corn for bread?
I think the Duke of Burgundy will fast
Before he'll buy again at such a rate:
'Twas full of darnel; do you like the taste?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BURGUNDY
SPEECH.LINE: Scoff on, vile fiend and shameless courtezan!
I trust ere long to choke thee with thine own
And make thee curse the harvest of that corn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHARLES
SPEECH.LINE: Your grace may starve perhaps before that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: O, let no words, but deeds, revenge this treason!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: What will you do, good grey-beard? break a lance,
And run a tilt at death within a chair?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Foul fiend of France, and hag of all despite,
Encompass'd with thy lustful paramours!
Becomes it thee to taunt his valiant age
And twit with cowardice a man half dead?
Damsel, I'll have a bout with you again,
Or else let Talbot perish with this shame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Are ye so hot, sir? yet, Pucelle, hold thy peace;
If Talbot do but thunder, rain will follow.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: The English whisper together in council
SPEECH.LINE: God speed the parliament! who shall be the speaker?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Dare ye come forth and meet us in the field?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Belike your lordship takes us then for fools,
To try if that our own be ours or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: I speak not to that railing Hecate,
But unto thee, Alencon, and the rest;
Will ye, like soldiers, come and fight it out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ALENCON
SPEECH.LINE: Signior, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Signior, hang! base muleters of France!
Like peasant foot-boys do they keep the walls
And dare not take up arms like gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JOAN LA PUCELLE
SPEECH.LINE: Away, captains! let's get us from the walls;
For Talbot means no goodness by his looks.
God be wi' you, my lord! we came but to tell you
That we are here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: And there will we be too, ere it be long,
Or else reproach be Talbot's greatest fame!
Vow, Burgundy, by honour of thy house,
Prick'd on by public wrongs sustain'd in France,
Either to get the town again or die:
And I, as sure as English Henry lives
And as his father here was conqueror,
As sure as in this late-betrayed town
Great Coeur-de-lion's heart was buried,
So sure I swear to get the town or die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BURGUNDY
SPEECH.LINE: My vows are equal partners with thy vows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: But, ere we go, regard this dying prince,
The valiant Duke of Bedford. Come, my lord,
We will bestow you in some better place,
Fitter for sickness and for crazy age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Talbot, do not so dishonour me:
Here will I sit before the walls of Rouen
And will be partner of your weal or woe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BURGUNDY
SPEECH.LINE: Courageous Bedford, let us now persuade you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Not to be gone from hence; for once I read
That stout Pendragon in his litter sick
Came to the field and vanquished his foes:
Methinks I should revive the soldiers' hearts,
Because I ever found them as myself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TALBOT
SPEECH.LINE: Undaunted spirit in a dying breast!
Then be it so: heavens keep old Bedford safe!
And now no more ado, brave Burgundy,
But gather we our forces out of hand
And set upon our boasting enemy.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but BEDFORD and Attendants
An alarum: excursions. Enter FASTOLFE and a Captain

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Captain
SPEECH.LINE: Whither away, Sir John Fastolfe, in such haste?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FASTOLFE
SPEECH.LINE: Whither away! to save myself by flight:
We are like to have the overthrow again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Captain
SPEECH.LINE: What! will you fly, and leave Lord Talbot?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FASTOLFE
SPEECH.LINE: Ay,
All the Talbots in the world, to save my life!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Captain
SPEECH.LINE: Cowardly knight! ill fortune follow thee!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Retreat: excursions. JOAN LA PUCELLE, ALENCON, and CHARLES fly

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BEDFORD
SPEECH.LINE: Now, quiet soul, depart when heaven please,
For I have seen our enemies' overthrow.
What is the trust or strength of foolish man?
